titleStmt.title: CW 117
titleStmt.author: Carmichael, Alexander Archibald (1832‐1912)
titleStmt.sponsor: Edinburgh University Library and the Department of Scottish and Celtic Studies

interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

lg.l: Na daoine dona / Daoine dona dona

p.del:
Deisein = Doison grass growing in corn
very small (Gomhun?(

div.p:
Rustic ChotageChottage, 40 yards on other
side of Manse MacConnich

Kate Macphail nee Ross Cinn
a choille - Bishop Kinkell -
My brother got a piece of awn in
his eye. He was suffsufferring agonieagony. I was
sent to Donald Macianamhuin
in Arcarn Urraidh. He made
the eolas smuir to my brothbrother
he placed the calg on the plate
about 4 inches away. He got
relief at this then said this calg put
out of the mansman's mouth

My master told me that his wife
did not sleep all last night from
a mote in her eye - would you
aft when you go home go and see
Bean Mhic Coinnich A man
went and told the name by
the woman Ceite Vic rath
Bean Mhic Connich made
the eolas. I think she will
be all right now she Bean
Mhic rath I marked the time 8-30
When I saw my gaffer I asked
him how his wife was. Now
she is all right. All at seen
last even at 8-30 she got relief
Alexander Campbell Cannuin

figure.figDesc: Very rough sketch showing stone five stones Stones 21 feet 21 feet x 2 out of several small stones on a cairn

div.p: Between Muir of Ord Urrad Church

MartMargaret Mackenzie cottar Urrad
17 AugAugust 1909

lg.l: Bha mi lalatha tightighinn s an Roimh
Nach she on PPeadair agagus Pol

div.p:
C This Eolas must be made
near water preferably near
running water with the foot upon
a stone.

Nebuchadnezer was
the name given to the woman
who went with the deer as he
went with his oxen

There is much talking of spirit called
Ly-Erg that frequents the Glen more
Arrman He appears with a red hand in th yet
habit offof a souldiersoldier & challanges
men to fight with him as lately
as 69 he fought with three
Brothers one after another who
immediately dyeddied thereafter.
Beinnein = Kingussie
James Macrae Laskardale ("Rat")

Maclean nee
Taigh a phreas
div.title: Casga fala

lg.l: Bha mi lathas ann an Roimh
Se dh ord.dh ordaich a dhomh

div.p:
ChaChaidh lalatha e mach buadh gun
altachadh

Casg an t' fhuil tri turais
Ri paidear (bo seven)

AnniAnnie MacKenzie } Both
Culbinnin Aiges } have casg
fala

Maclennan
crofter

My brother and I were working
down at the Cannonach, we
were sitting eating hard biscuits
I noticed that my brothbrother had
not finishfinished his. I struck his
hand from below and threw
up the half eaten bistbiscuit. It
but went in his eye. He suffersuffered
great pain for two days.
Angus Strathy came and carried
my brother up to an old womwoman
at Fairburn Tower The womwoman
put two three pebbles in a small basin
tub of water and said a rann. The
bit of bisbiscuit came upon his palm
of her hand. MacKenzie or
my brother recognised this bit
of biscuit and so did use
all. She was at Braigh Arcain.
Cridh aotrom is sporan trom

Ma sibh a nis a falbh agus a fag­
ail chuir daoine agus bhun dubh
a luaidh mo chridhe O mata
gu mi slan a itheas sibh
agus gu mi mu h-innsih dhuibh a
dheandeanadh
Hake = Fence of Gates

BuringBurying under foundation
common in China
wrote Mr Watson about a
rock in earth.
Duradan = Dust in the eye.

No singing at the baking for
fear any flew from the mouth
All labour had itits song and
music saving baking

No children allowed to walk
on middle of road - at night
lest a funeral should meet
them. To avoid machines on
the road

lg.l: Lit is lagan biadh an duiduine ladlàidir -

div.p:
Lagan was the lagan cam
was taken with porridge

Duine air fhacal
Us each air thaod
A man of honour

An diugh ag eiridh
Duair ghabh 3 DDaoine LLàidir aoin chruibh
GleadhGleadhadh e bho mhomhoch gu dubh
Cosda Two crofters ploughing together.

29
July
1909 Searbanach - This is the plant
Angus Ross used in casga
fala. 5 ftfeet 9 high chest
very round - man very strong
He has the head of a god body as
a tree. Powerful crofter.
The power to stop blood is from
God not from me. I ask him
and he gives
Cumar = Narrow, = Cumhann

div.p:
Three kind in nes

Tha mi ag guidh sa gadhail
Gun tog tu am falbh am
Gun san cridhe dhi te seo

div.p:
†
In the holy name of
Jesus
Pray for the soul of
John Sobieski rStuart
Count D' Albanie
Who died 13 February 1872
Aged 74 years

Eternal Rest Give Unto Him
O Lord
R I PRequiescat In Pace

31 March 1826
John Fraser Churchill EdinbEdinburgh
born West Easkadale' Beauly.

†
To his dear memory
This monument is erected
By
Georgina Stuart
Countess D Albanie
His Widow
Who beseeches the faithful
of their charity when her short
sad days are past to pray
for her soul be likewise

Friday 6th AugAugust 1909
In Eisgeadal Church
Eilean Aigeis Gaelic

Bo a Srath Narran

Sagart us ceann ruadh air

ChaiChaidh an gille leis an t searbhsearbhanta

an Ionnar Gharraidh
Tha thu cho dona ris an tuath
an Ionnar Gharraidh

ruith air an taobh cham ach
drochddrochaid. Chan fhaodafhaodadh facal cainnt tigh
inn as bhur ceann gun an tig
dachaidh.

An corr burn a dhort air
chlach mor ach gabh gluas
ad
Feum aig a bhi ann an
anam mas an "chatear"

Ainm an duine no
a bheothaich ra innse

The woman was feeding him but
spilt some of the egg over his mouth
Mo ruiteachan mo ruiteachan
ars an te thainig dhachaidh
S seach mo bhial a chaidh e ars
leanabh Ileach

For gravel
Rulgue -
Clerk cheviot
Churchhill EdinbuEdinburgh

Taken like tea Iain Friseal
Lochlait, Abriachan

fhichadfhichead na talmhainn
A man in Urachadan made
a bottle of each

For fire wood = seargag
Athla = heifer

Warts
Go to church yard and dip your
warts in water in curves in stone
graves. This will put them
away in no time.

Druim an Dorsair Cill mor
of Beaulay17 AugAugust 1909 6 pm
AlexAlexander Cameron 81 aged
Cleans

div.p:

nearly 40 years ago (in 1871)
from two women there - two
good women

Sug Sguchadh Tarbh
Friday 20 AugtAugust 1909

lg.title: Eolas A Chaimein
lg.l: Tha mis a cur ri iuil

div.p:
Issie Ross Munro nee Ross
Aich chroine Cinne chardinn
Ross Saturday 21 AugAugust 1909

An ainm an AAthair MMac Sp Spiorad Naoimh
Mar mismise a deandeanamh so a spion­
adh a chearbarnaich. A ag
ain an t ait as an robh
an fhuil a tightighinn agus cha
ann neach air a bheathaich
cha stad air an fhuil.
Cha n fhaod iarran dol
na choir ga bhuan ag
stron fhad friamh bruich.
Brac = Catch wtwith cut ones

The sguch takes the same time
healing it took getting - a few
minutes or a few weeks. If
in brnactinnstinneas Snath lin is best.

My mother sent me evryevery nignight
to the barn to the baile = cross bar
to exercize my self and swing myself
to and fro on the baile

div.head: Cron suil
div.p:
A man
from
Baid­eanach
Mum buibuidhe air do shuil
When a person admired his goats
Fear falbhan nan gobhar
Do shuil fothad
Do shuil na do thoin
Do shuil fothad cohaircothair he needneeded
to be polite

Ghoir a chorra-sgriach
oirbh - faod faodaidh eibh chuid
clachadh bhon iasgach

Murray Farm Grieve
Arcan Urrad

He was carrying home peat
when a bit of peat went in
his eye. The woman Edderton
offered him a dram. He said I
would rather you would dradraw
the thing from my eye. WhatWhat's
wrong with your eye? A bit
of peat culm is in it. I will
soon remove that said she She
got a basin of water saying
a rhyme and thus should he
the bit peat in the water.
He acknowledged that this
thing was out of his eye and
that he had relief.

Maclean told me this
21 AugAugust 1909

A man in Lochs Lews went to
Australia an toir an fhortain
he was to send home for his wife
and children as soon as he was
able. One year passed two yrsyears
passed and three years passed
and no word came from this man
Then his wife went to a woman
The woman asked how long
since he left how long since
she heard from him &c &c.

The woman went into a trance
and was apparently dead. She
wakened up said Tha'n duine
agad na leithid seo a dh aite
chan ann lan air do shual
thus' Tha e slan fallain ach
cha do chnamh an saoghal
leis agus cha do sgriobh e
thugad ach sgriobhsgriobhaidh e thugadh
gun dail.

An ceann tri miosan an diugh
sin thainig litir bhon duine
ann an thubhairt e An deach
thu ann an leithid seo a latha
mun mo dheighinnsa chun
uair bu chnamh ann an
Bhuail anns mar
nach do bhuail riamh romhroimhe
ann agus bha mi ris a bhas
fad fichead mionadmionaid na
h-uarach agus chunna mi
am boirioneach ma ma
choinneamh &c &c.

Three young people scrape the
back of a cow hide bound
The cow is tied up by the head and
cannot move her head al
sorely troubled. They sing in chorus

Had been in the war camcame
home full of praise and
honour. He had been in the
beinn-sheilg and when
a snow storm came on and
he was smothered beside his
own garden wall close
to his house - He was
a famous swordsman
the most famous in his
day - He could cut the button
from the neck of his opponents
shirt. His tomb is in this
church at Rodail with the
figure of a man as with
sword in full length on
his stone. Hewed in Geo­
Crab Harris

Widow Sandy Mackay Taynamfaoilinn
AlbeaAltbea. Ask him for the man
in Gearrloch who has casga
fala.
Magairle Garbh = sea urchin
Cam slaod = slaodag

An t eolas Balbh = goimh a
thoirt a losgadh
Reiteach = Leobhnachas = posadh

lg.l: DheanninDheannain sugradh Ris an ninnighean duibh
Duan a shaoil gun e dh fhan mi
Ealasaid a cheann a bha agad
Dol tromh Mhaol na h Or
Cha robh fear nan meang airgid
Thug e cnamh as each briste

Air aimn tri peara na
TrianTrianaid

div.title: An Tarbhan
div.p:
We had a stirk and was swollen
greatly. My father went to Mary
Mackenzie Badfearn. She
came and went sun wise
round the stirk repeating
a rann in name of the Trinity
and when the stirk got up and
began to graze and the swelling
went down - subsided

div.title: The Cioch
div.p:
Had the cioch fallen. My
went father went to this woman
and she made the Eolas
na ciche to me and immimmediately
the uvula went its place
in Meallan Thearlaich
thu Cioch Thraght was put
on this sloinntireadh. The
cioch rose quickly and gently
The blood of a black cat
or black cock mar
iobart fhala do Dhia
for falling sickness

div.title: Eolas an Tarbhan
div.p:
From Ann Morrison crofter
Bad fearn Alltbeath 4th SepSeptember 09

An leigheas a chchuir CXCriosda
Dha A bho na caillich
Casan muin is casan tri
Cas a fuith 'sa lodar
Tha aon feith dhiag air
fhichead ann an seach bo
Tha te na te na h ath s bu
te ann Tha gach aonar
ann sin ag iarraidh
leigheas

Tha sid dha do leigheas
A Nios Bhuidh
She put the caba larr in
the fist till the whole swelling
went away. As the iron
water the she swelling went
Any piece of iron in the ground
Socladh = moderately - in rain &c

William Dingwall crofter
Strath Gearrloch
6th SeptSeptember 1909. 78 years of age

lg.l: Paidear Moire SeachSeachd An ann an AthAthar Sa MMhic s SpSpioraid Naomh

div.p:
Ga dh radh tri turas
An ainm an athathar
He keeps the thread in his mouth
he does not put knots on
the thread - he does not
believe in them - in knots

He often did this and to good
effect. He never did this to
a brute beast - only to human
beings

8th SeptSeptember 9091909 Carn Dearg
Gearrloch -

John MacKenzie of Altbeatha
smith - said the cioch fell
and for some days I was unable
to speak to William Campbell
Ciad Ensire to cure me. The
messenger had hardly time
to be at his house when this
cioch rose with snap. I was
Altbeath - some forfour or five
miles away. He did this to many
The messenger told him my
name and he went through
the prayer.

Isabell Chisholm nee MacKenzie
Meallabhaig (22 Lot)
8 SeptSeptember 1909

The Gulmamum grows like
a scale of herring.

An t-Eolas Gulmain
I take up water drawdrawn the
fiar over the eye thee times
after dipping in the water
uisg as a chaochain stream
let I place this in a bottle
and dip the grass in it and
then draw the grass over the
eyeball three times
A white Glob comes upon the eye.

div.title: Uisg Airgid
div.p:
An an A Athar MhMhic SSpioraid Naomh
Tha mi togail seo gu do
Tha mi toir tri strupaga
dha neach tha tinn. Sput
a chailbh an na bonais
aig an neach sprinkle a
dheanabh air aodain le
uisge

div.title: Sgucha Feithe
div.p: Alexander Mackenzie, Allt Griosan

lg.l: S fhuair e casan nan each
Ann am luchd ma seach XCriosda

div.p:
Three knots on the thread and
each placed to the lips

Tolm = The thread put on the sgucha
feith

div.title: Beothach a Dh ith Biast
div.p:
Balgan beiste A globe with an
insect inside This was kept and
when a cow ate an insect this
was put in water a dhealbhadh
an uisge sprinked on the cow.

RuaraiRuaraidh Matheson
Ath-nan ceann Ceannloch
ewe Hotel there.
Has Eolas an Tarbhas

div.title: Sgoich
div.p:
If the sgoich is cut it will
not come out through the
skin

If the ara of the rabbit are
eaten first the other ara cannot
come
Gearrloch saying

Orthan =
Boslach = Infant baptism

When a man was put out of
the ceilidh for not having a story
He called out "Fear ionad fear
Ionad" - a man came forward
SiudSiuthad tha mise seo ga do shaoradh
He then got back. If he had a
sean fhacal he got off.

Ruaraidh Macpherson crofter
Nastaidh Gearrloch Disabhan
11th SepSeptember 1909

lg.l: CxCriosda a leighis do chois laimh

div.p: Cha do rinneadh an Roimh comhearadh

div.title: Christ on the Cross
div.p:
There was no bellows and the
bana-cheard blew the fire over
her sguird apron and the nails
for the cross were made. Then
CChrist said Bis tusa a siubhail
bho linnean na linnean agus
do sheors as do dheigh airson
do ghniomh agus chan fhaigh
thus fois oicheoidhche no tamh lalatha

Carsail } Byre drain
Cladhan }

div.title: Christ
div.p:
And his mothmother came to a house
where the woman was suffering
from at cich. Thuirt easa
ri mhathair an an t at uile
a leigheas Leighs thusa at cich
bho s tu Dia nan feart
ChruinnChruinnich CXCriosda agus thubhairt
Gum bu gil a bhios do nelbhian
Gum bu crion a bhios an t at
Dh fhalbh e
I healdhealed ten or twelve cases
of the rose immediately here
and in Morayshire.

div.title: An Gulman
div.p:
Uisge seimh as soitheach slan
Tha mi togail seo an ainm
An AthAthair MMac SpSpiorad
An t ainm baiste a seo
The must be a sixpensixpence or a 1/
in the bottom of the basin
The lus is an tri bhliadhach(?)

Ainite = beothach mor boirion
Heifer (seasg)

lg.l: An t eolseolas ri Calum cille

div.add: Three times had to be said

div.title: The Earnach
div.p:
An cannach dhearg
An cannach ghlas
Causes blood in cows - red blood
on grass bleeding. Sugh
Pronn sugh cath bhios tighe
as a mhuin to the cow ill with
the same

div.title: Greim mionnaich
div.p: Catherine Maclean again

Thainig fear coigcoigreach an oicheoidhche
agus dh iarr e cead fuireach. ThuThubhairt
a bhean nach faighfhaigh - ThuThubhairt
am fear gum faigh
Chuir an coigcoigreach dhan t sobhal
agus na laighe air calg
an eorna

Bhuail greim mionnaich
fear an tighe agus b fheirrde
dhan bhean dol agus an
coigcoigreach a dhusgadh. Thainig
an coigcoigreach agus thubhairt e
A bhean dhian a bhean dhian
Agus fear fialaidh
Agus CCriosda na laighe air
a chalg

Se sin leigheas an t-seirg
Seirg-greim mionnaich
Tha mionnaich a cuireadh
na chnap cruaidh

Mr Urquhart of
Faithir MhorGearrloch told
me that the battle of Omduir
man was known in the marks
of cairns hours before it was
known by the telegraph the distance
being fifteen miles away. The
battle of the massacre of
Cawnpore was known
further India
The news caused much excitement among
all classes

div.title: Gulman
div.p:
Alexander Urquhart an 'Gaidheal'
tailor Gearrloch

lg.l: An t ainm s an sloinneadh
An t ainm s an sloinneadh

div.p:
Na seachd spairn sin
Air ordugh Dhe
Leighis do shuill sa
"Iain Rois"
Fiar glas agus airgid geal
Ann an ainm Dhe
Leighis do shuil Iain Rois

Gold and silver must be in
the basin of water. The basin
must not be put on the lar
nor on a stone but upon a fiodh
The grass and the gold and
the silver are moved to the eye
and the water poured upon
the eyeball - to clean the
eye.

I cured at least forty of
this thing in my day - I can
say no more about it except
that they all got better - Some
of the cases came long
I put the water on the eye
and the hand upon the eye.

Fēth fīthe =
Lac Lait = Iona brink of sleep
Cailcein = Land bank of sea
bank raised above its surroundings

div.title: Ora Sgocha feithe

lg.l: Air an asail dheis og bha grinn
A leigheas gach creuchd agus plaigh
'S ag aisig gu slainte na bha tinn,
Thug Esan a radharcfhradharc do'n dall
'S Do'n bhacach thug imeachd gu reidh
Le Peadar 's le Pal 's le Muire bean aigh

Biodh dluth an drasda a leigheas
nan cnamh 's nam feith
Suaathadh is sile is luibh Chaluim‐Chille
Suathadh is sile is luibh Chaluim-Chille

Suathadh is sile is pog an
Spiorad Amen

div.p:
From A.Alexander Camashron.
(Bard Thournaig). Poolewe

A.Alexander Cameron. Achadh Mor. Poolewe.
Bard Thournaig 13-9-09

lg.l:
Deanam-sa dhuit eolas
gu casg beum-sula
Ma 's si suil fir i bhN

Mas si suil mnatha i
bhi easbudh a ciche

Falcadair fuar agus
fuarachd d'a fuil
Air a cuidh air a coaraich
Air a cuid air a daoine fhein

div.p:
Bha iad a buain tri
bileagan feoir ann
an ainm na Trianaid
agus ga chur ann am
botul is a cur stJall
mhath uisge air is 'ga
chrathadh; bha iad
ga thaomadh air an
earrann ghoirt 's aig
an cheudna a radh -
nam facail so:-

The father is not allowed to

still born or unbaptised child He

div.title: Droch shuil
div.p:
WmWilliam Mac coinnich mason
Anaid Loch ToirbheartToirbheartan
17 16 SeptSeptember 1909

My father was ploughing in spring
when a man from Coire came
for seed oats. Immediately he left
the lair fell beside the gearran
My father went to this atha
and told his father. Its the eye
of that fell
upon the mare Siubhal agus till -
Thill an duine ars an
duine agus chaidh e deiseil
an lair a seinn rann agus
a muin oirre. Dh eirich an
lair agus chrath is e fhein
agus chuir i a guala ris a bheud
agus hairrintharruing i annan crann.

Scrot = Shelf in rock

Creag an Fhithich - north end
of rock has letter of some sort on
the rock. No person has been able
to make out what the writing is. There
are two parallel caves both very
deep - one inacessibleinaccessible. The other
had been lived in - full of shells.

Croulin ghlas an ime - Fine

butter here is as sweet as honey.
